newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil needs "total abstinence" from inflation.
newsitem.headline: Brazil needs "total abstinence" from inflation.

text.p: Like a reformed alcoholic, only total abstinence will cure Brazil from the hyperinflation of the past, Central Bank Director of Monetary Policy Francisco "Chico" Lopes said in an interview published Sunday.
"In Brazil, if we had inflation of 50 or 60 percent, we would sink straight back into hyperinflation," Lopes told Globo newspaper.
"It would be a social catastrophe. We are like former alcoholics and only total abstinence will cure us," he said.
The Brazilian government's "Plano Real" economic stability plan has successfully brought inflation down from a peak of almost 5,000 percent a year three years ago to about 10 percent last year.
As he and other officials have done all week, Lopes ruled out any change in foreign exchange or monetary policy in the wake of currency devaluations in Asia.
Market jitters over a possible domino effect, forcing a Brazilian devaluation, pounded stocks in Sao Paulo and across the region this week, shaving more than 10 percent off the Bovespa stock index.
But Lopes said Brazil was completely committed to stability and the fight against inflation, and would stick to its forex and monetary policies until full stability was assured.
"During this transition, which could take years, we will have the vulnerability of a wide current account deficit and dependency on external financing," he said.
Lopes criticized Thailand, the first of the so-called "Asian Tigers" to succumb to currency speculators, for allowing its currency to devaluate.
"Thailand will pay dearly for this. Thailand is trying to do something impossible: remain an Asian Tiger when it no longer is."
Lopes also insisted that Brazil was committed to controlling public spending because "if we lose discipline in our economic policy, we make ourselves vulnerable to attack," he said.
